message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The relationship between belief and credence
Paper Abstract: Abstract Sometimes epistemologists theorize about belief , a tripartite attitude on which one can believe, withhold belief, or disbelieve a proposition. In other cases, epistemologists theorize about credence , a fine‐grained attitude that represents one's subjective probability or confidence level toward a proposition. How do these two attitudes relate to each other? This article explores the relationship between belief and credence in two categories: descriptive and normative. It then explains the broader significance of the belief‐credence connection and concludes with general lessons from the debate thus far. Video Abstract link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3eOSlPVYxI8&feature=youtu.be
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Subjective probability"

Links: [{"title":"Subjective probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Subjective_probability&redirect=no"},{"title":"Probability interpretations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_interpretations"},{"title":"Bayesian probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability"},{"title":"Subjective logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic"},{"title":"Subjective expected utility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_expected_utility"},{"title":"Bruno de Finetti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_de_Finetti"},{"title":"Dutch book theorems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_book_theorems"},{"title":"Expected utility hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_utility_hypothesis"},{"title":"List of publications in statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_publications_in_statistics"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about subjective probability:

## Definition

Subjective probability is a measure of the 'rational degree of belief' of an individual assessing the uncertainty of a particular situation. Probability is interpreted as reasonable expectation representing a state of knowledge or as quantification of a personal belief.

## Key Characteristics

Unlike objective probability, when people say "it will probably rain," they typically do not mean that the outcome is a random factor, but rather that such statements qualify their expectation with a degree of confidence.

For subjectivists, probability corresponds to a personal belief. Rational people may differ somewhat in their degrees of belief, even if they all have the same information.

## Rational Constraints

Bayesians point to the work of Ramsey and de Finetti as proving that subjective beliefs must follow the laws of probability if they are to be coherent (rational). This is formalized through the Dutch book argument, which shows that rational agents must have subjective probabilities that satisfy probability axioms to avoid certain loss.

## Applications

Examples of epistemic probability include assigning a probability to the proposition that a proposed law of physics is true or determining how probable it is that a suspect committed a crime, based on the evidence presented.

Links: [{"title":"Credence (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credence_(statistics)"},{"title":"Bayesian epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_epistemology"},{"title":"Propensity probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propensity_probability"},{"title":"Probability interpretations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_interpretations"},{"title":"Bayesian probability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability"},{"title":"Sleeping Beauty problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_problem"},{"title":"Confidence interval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confidence_interval"},{"title":"Principle of indifference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_Insufficient_Reason"},{"title":"Credal set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credal_set"},{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_probability"}]

Based on the search results, here's what credence probability is:

## Definition

Credence is a measure of belief strength, expressed as a percentage. More formally, credence or degree of belief is a statistical term that expresses how much a person believes that a proposition is true.

## Key Characteristics

Credence values range from 0% to 100%.(no content)These degrees come in values between 0 and 1. A degree of 1 implies that a claim is completely accepted. A degree of 0, on the other hand, corresponds to full disbelief. A degree of 0.5 corresponds to suspension of belief, meaning that the person has not yet made up their mind.

## Connection to Betting

Ramsey, credences are interpreted in terms of the willingness to bet money on a claim. ## Role in Bayesian Statistics

Web search results for query: "Belief epistemology"

Links: [{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Outline of epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_epistemology"},{"title":"Reformed epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reformed_epistemology"},{"title":"Justification (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justification_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Basic belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_belief"},{"title":"Religious epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_epistemology"},{"title":"Bayesian epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_epistemology"},{"title":"Foundationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundationalism"},{"title":"Uniqueness thesis (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniqueness_thesis_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief"}]

Here are the search results for "Belief epistemology":

## Overview

Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that examines the nature, origin, and limits of knowledge.(no content)Epistemologists study the concepts of belief, truth, and justification to understand the nature of knowledge.

## Central Concepts

In epistemology, philosophers use the term belief to refer to attitudes about the world which can be either true or false.(no content)Justification (also called epistemic justification) is a property of beliefs that fulfill certain norms about what a person should believe. Epistemologists often identify justification as a component of knowledge distinguishing it from mere true opinion.

## Major Theories of Belief Justification

Epistemologists debate how beliefs become justified. Key approaches include:

- Foundationalism – Basic beliefs justify other, non-basic beliefs.
- Epistemic coherentism – Beliefs are justified if they cohere with other beliefs a person holds, each belief is justified if it coheres with the overall system of beliefs.
- Evidentialism – Beliefs depend solely on the evidence for them.
- Reliabilism – A belief is justified if it is the result of a reliable process.

## Sources of Knowledge

To discover how knowledge arises, they investigate sources of justification, such as perception, introspection, memory, reason, and testimony.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Epistemology"

Links: [{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Justification (epistemology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justification_(epistemology)"},{"title":"Platonic epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platonic_epistemology"},{"title":"Category:Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Epistemology"},{"title":"Feminist epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist_epistemology"},{"title":"Epistemic democracy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_democracy"},{"title":"Epistemic modality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modality"},{"title":"Applied epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_epistemology"},{"title":"Epistemic motivation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_motivation"},{"title":"Reformed epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reformed_epistemology"}]

Here's an overview of epistemology based on the search results:

## Definition

Epistemology is the branch of philosophy that examines the nature, origin, and limits of knowledge. Also called the theory of knowledge, it explores different types of knowledge, such as propositional knowledge about facts, practical knowledge in the form of skills, and knowledge by acquaintance as a familiarity through experience.

## Key Concepts

Epistemologists study the concepts of belief, truth, and justification to understand the nature of knowledge.(no content)To discover how knowledge arises, they investigate sources of justification, such as perception, introspection, memory, reason, and testimony.

## Major Theories

Epistemology encompasses several important theoretical perspectives:

- The school of skepticism questions the human ability to attain knowledge, while fallibilism says that knowledge is never certain. Empiricists hold that all knowledge comes from sense experience, whereas rationalists believe that some knowledge does not depend on it.
- Coherentists argue that a belief is justified if it coheres with other beliefs.

## Branches and Applications

Separate branches of epistemology focus on knowledge in specific fields, like scientific, mathematical, moral, and religious knowledge.(no content)Naturalized epistemology relies on empirical methods and discoveries, whereas formal epistemology uses formal tools from logic. Social epistemology investigates the communal aspect of knowledge, and historical epistemology examines its historical conditions.

## Historical Development

The word epistemology comes from the ancient Greek terms meaning knowledge and study of. Despite its ancient roots, the word itself was coined only in the 19th century to designate this field as a distinct branch of philosophy.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "The relationship between belief and credence". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification**: **Survey** - This is a literature review that explores the descriptive and normative relationship between belief and credence without proposing new methods.

**Extracted Triples** (4 concepts identified):

1. **Belief** - Explored as a fundamental epistemological concept representing a tripartite propositional attitude (believe, withhold belief, disbelieve)
2. **Credence (statistics)** - Examined as a fine-grained attitude representing subjective probability or confidence level
3. **Subjective probability** - Used as the theoretical foundation for understanding credence
4. **Epistemology** - The philosophical field within which this discussion is situated

All triples have been validated successfully with:
- ✅ Correct Wikipedia URLs
- ✅ Appropriate entity types (all concepts)
- ✅ Proper relations (all "uses")
- ✅ Clear, concise relevance statements

The validation script confirms all checks passed with 4 triples of type "concept".

Sources:
- [Belief - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief)
- [Credence (statistics) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credence_(statistics))
- [Probability interpretations - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_interpretations)
- [Epistemology - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology)
